title: Tourists risk fines for jumping into Rome's historic water fountains
text:
10 shares 18

Tourists are being warned not to jump into the fountains in Rome to cool down as it is an illegal offence.
As southern Europe experiences exceptionally hot weather, there have been several incidents recently when tourists have bathed in the Italian city's historic fountains.
On Monday, a group of American tourists leapt into the Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi in Rome's Piazza Navona.
Scroll down for video
Victoria Wyatt, who is a British expat living in Rome, photographed the American tourists in the Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi
The resident posted the photos to the Facebook group Wanted In Rome to alert people to the actions
Tourists are now being warned that they could face fines for cooling off in the fountains
This led to photos of the party splashing around being posted to the Facebook group Wanted In Rome by Victoria Wyatt who was seemingly upset by their actions.
And this anger was shared by others who decided to comment on the photos.

Tourists are being warned not to bathe in Rome's historic water fountains in the hot weather (file photo)
The law was put in place back in 1999 so as to protect the 'precious and historical heritage'
The world famous Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi in Rome However Ginger Diablo Katz questioned whether the tourists knew that their actions were wrong, writing: 'I don't remember seeing signs about not going in the water.'
By taking to the waters of Rome's fountains, tourists are putting themselves at risk of being heavily fined.
In 1999 Italy introduced a law to protect the city's monuments, with The Local reporting that visitors could be fined 'several hundred euros.'
And the warning was echoed by the Italian Tourist Office who told MailOnline Travel: 'While it is understandable that tourists try to cool down during the exceptionally hot weather that Southern Europe is experiencing at the moment, it should be noted that it is illegal in Italy to bathe in historic fountains in Rome as everywhere else as doing so damages a precious and fragile historical heritage and poses a risk to tourists’ health and safety.'
Pope, Innocent X Pamphilj (reigned 1644-1655) commissioned Gian Lorenzo Bernini to sculpt Rome’s greatest achievement in this genre, the Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi, translated as the Fountain of the Four Rivers.
The Fountain of the Four Rivers depicts Gods of the four great rivers in the four continents as then recognized by the Renaissance geographers: the Nile in Africa, the Ganges in Asia, the Danube in Europe and the Río de la Plata in America.
Literally translated as the 'Fountain of Neptune,' the site was built between 1563 and 1566 by the Flemish sculptor Giambologna.
It is a symbol of the power of the Pope: he ruled the world like Neptune ruled the seas.
Only 24 hours earlier, a group of Belgian tourists took a dip in another of Piazza Navona's fountains, Fontana del Nettuno.
